entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Respect overscroll-behavior on non-scrollable scroll containers
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Respect overscroll-behavior on non-scrollable scroll containers
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Respect+overscroll%5C-behavior+on+non%5C-scrollable+scroll+containers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Respect overscroll-behavior on non-scrollable scroll containers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Philip+J%C3%A4genstedt%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Philip Jägenstedt</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250917" rel="nofollow">Wed, 17 Sep 2025 08:29:14 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>We discussed this at the API owners meeting today. (Present: Daniel, Yoav, Alex, Chris, Mike, Dan, Vlad, me.)</pre><pre>
LGTM1
Based on the use counter (8%) and the number of sites checked (10) we don't have high confidence that this won't break something. However, we also don't have a concrete way to further reduce the uncertainty beyond manually checking hundreds of sites and making a judgment call about whether each is improved or not, which does not feel reasonable.
Instead, to shake out as much breakage as we can, we'd like to let this bake at 100% on beta for ~4 weeks (one extra milestone) and monitor for bugs. If there's nothing concerning, then launch at 100% on stable, while being prepared to revert if there are reports at that point.
If you could report back here before going to stable that would be great, but no further approvals needed if things are looking good.
On Wed, Sep 17, 2025 at 5:11 PM Alex Russell <slightly...@chromium.org> wrote:
> Thanks. I'm pinging people. Hopefully folks can weigh in here quickly. > > On Tuesday, September 16, 2025 at 7:11:54 AM UTC-7 Robert Flack wrote: > >> I completely agree, the point here isn't to follow the spec. The reason I >> think we should follow the spec in this case is that it is more ergonomic >> and predictable when applying overscroll-behavior doesn't just work >> sometimes. I think that developers are rightfully confused by those cases >> where it doesn't work which is why we have had several bugs filed about it. >> >> I have reached out to a few web developers. If you know anyone who might >> have thoughts on this please loop them in as well. >> >> On Mon, Sep 15, 2025 at 2:00 PM Alex Russell <slightly...@chromium.org> >> wrote: >> >>> I'd love for web developers who have been paying close attention to >>> scroll behaviour to weigh in here. This has been a deep well of sadness in >>> a cross-browser sense, and they might have opinions as to the benefits and >>> costs we aren't able to easily see. Spec compliance can either be great or >>> pointless, and it would be helpful to get a sense from folks building >>> complex UIs which this is. >>> >>> Best, >>> >>> Alex >>> >>> On Friday, September 12, 2025 at 10:53:50 AM UTC-7 Robert Flack wrote: >>> >>>> > is there any plausible pattern where web developers could depend on >>>> the current behavior intentionally? >>>> >>>> The change in behavior comes in roughly three patterns: >>>> >>>> 1. overscroll-behavior: contain | none is specified on an element >>>> with overflow: hidden. In these cases the overscroll-behavior used >>>> to have no effect, scrolls would propagate past the element to ancestor >>>> scrollers. In practice, when a developer has specified this they likely >>>> intended to prevent scroll propagation, however due to the >>>> implementation >>>> it had no effect. Authors typically try to do this to prevent scrolling >>>> while a modal dialog is open from scrolling the content behind it, e.g. >>>> as >>>> in the example posted to the bug >>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072</a>> >>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj">https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj</a>. >>>> 2. The author specified overscroll-behavior: contain | none but on >>>> an element with overflow-y: scroll | auto (but implicit overflow-x: >>>> hidden). In this case, they may have accidentally applied >>>> overscroll-behavior to both axes and not realized that by spec this >>>> prevents overscroll propagation in both axes. I observed this on >>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://lichess.org/">https://lichess.org/</a> though blocking horizontal scrolls on the open >>>> menu would not break using the site. >>>> 3. The author specified overscroll-behavior: contain | none on an >>>> element with overflow: scroll | auto. In this case, we have the >>>> unpredictable behavior that when you have overflow it prevents >>>> propagation, >>>> but if your containing element is large enough for its content then we >>>> don't. This is the common case for things like scrolling in a chat >>>> widget ( >>>> demo <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://output.jsbin.com/helovikizu">https://output.jsbin.com/helovikizu</a>>, bug >>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40748098">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40748098</a>>) or in an embedded >>>> frame (bug <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40736788">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40736788</a>>). >>>> >>>> Case 1 and 2 are sort of the same, overflow: hidden now preventing >>>> scroll propagation, but in case 1 it never did anything before so it feels >>>> similar to an author using a property that doesn't work yet. >>>> >>>> If we want to be conservative, we could only change the behavior for >>>> cases where it is currently layout dependent, i.e. case 3 overflow: >>>> auto | scroll. This would be an improvement however it wouldn't help >>>> with case 1 where you want to prevent scrolling from your component without >>>> risking that containing element becoming scrollable. Cases 1 and 2 are >>>> possible that developers are relying on this being incorrectly ignored and >>>> not preventing scroll propagation on overflow: hidden, similar to for >>>> example ignoring left or top on position: static. >>>> >>>> That said, I do think it would be more useful and predictable for it to >>>> apply to all scroll containers as it is spec'd. >>>> >>>> On Fri, Sep 12, 2025 at 4:15 AM Philip Jägenstedt <foo...@chromium.org> >>>> wrote: >>>> >>>>> Hey Rob, >>>>> >>>>> Since the use counter is 8%, looking at 10 random popular sites >>>>> doesn't reduce the upper bound of breakage by a whole lot. Using the rule >>>>> of three <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_</a>(statistics)> gives >>>>> 95% confidence that the rate of breakage is between 0 and 30%. But 30% of >>>>> 8% is still a huge number when it comes to potential breakage. (Reducing >>>>> this to a reasonable number with more random sampling isn't really >>>>> feasible >>>>> either, you'd need to test 800 sites with only negatives to get down to >>>>> 0.03% if my math is right.) >>>>> >>>>> The fact that the change seems to make things work better and aligns >>>>> with apparent developer intention is great. But is there any plausible >>>>> pattern where web developers could depend on the current behavior >>>>> intentionally? >>>>> >>>>> In a situation like this I think we should also consider how many >>>>> sites we fix and not just how many we break. If we have high confidence >>>>> that many sites will be improved but can't find any that would regress, >>>>> then that seems like a good trade even if some regressions do surface. >>>>> >>>>> If other vendors are interested in making the same change and there's >>>>> clear developer demand, I think we should try it, with a Finch kill switch >>>>> in place. >>>>> >>>>> Best regards, >>>>> Philip >>>>> >>>>> On Thu, Sep 11, 2025 at 10:13 PM Robert Flack <fla...@chromium.org> >>>>> wrote: >>>>> >>>>>> Note that this is a repost of >>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/p2edIq4J-eQ/m/5MxPnuT8AwAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/p2edIq4J-eQ/m/5MxPnuT8AwAJ</a> >>>>>> as an I2S instead of PSA as I am seeking and will await LGTMs considering >>>>>> the potential compat risk. >>>>>> >>>>>> On the associated bug I have looked at a sampling of 10 popular >>>>>> sites affected by the overscroll-behavior change on httparchive >>>>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45</a>> and found it >>>>>> to either not impact them or be beneficial: >>>>>> 1. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://lichess.org/">https://lichess.org/</a> On smaller screens the `#topnav` element >>>>>> opens in a menu. The application of overscroll behavior seems to be there >>>>>> to prevent scrolling the content and so this site will be improved by the >>>>>> change. >>>>>> 2. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://cardgames.io/">https://cardgames.io/</a> Seems to just be the body element that has >>>>>> overscrollBehavior set. This shouldn't be affected. >>>>>> 3. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://open.spotify.com/">https://open.spotify.com/</a> The body and "your library" panel fit >>>>>> into this case. I think this change would apply the intended behavior as >>>>>> they do not seem to intend for the scroll to propagate. >>>>>> 4. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.accuweather.com/">https://www.accuweather.com/</a> Only the body has overscroll >>>>>> behavior specified. >>>>>> 5. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.ikea.com/">https://www.ikea.com/</a> Their mobile menu `#top-mobile-menu` has >>>>>> overscroll-behavior on it. This is presumably to prevent accidental pull >>>>>> to >>>>>> refresh while scrolling through the menu and would be fixed by this >>>>>> change. >>>>>> 6. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.tiktok.com/explore">https://www.tiktok.com/explore</a> The side nav has contain >>>>>> overscroll-behavior. With this change you would no longer be able to >>>>>> scroll >>>>>> the main page by scrolling on top of the sidebar. This seems to be the >>>>>> intention but is not currently being honored. >>>>>> 7. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://x.com/">https://x.com/</a> Only the root element seems to have >>>>>> overscroll-behavior defined. >>>>>> 8. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://store.epicgames.com/">https://store.epicgames.com/</a> I'm unable to find the affected >>>>>> element >>>>>> 9. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.airbnb.com/">https://www.airbnb.com/</a> There are several scrolling containers >>>>>> with overscroll-behavior defined however I think these are only "not >>>>>> scrollable" while the page is loading. By the time the user interacts >>>>>> with >>>>>> them they have scrollable overflow and so are unaffected. The usage also >>>>>> seems to indicate they would not want scroll to chain past those >>>>>> containers. >>>>>> 10. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.expedia.com/">https://www.expedia.com/</a> I'm not able to find where the property >>>>>> is used. >>>>>> >>>>>> In terms of developer demand, there are many bugs that have been >>>>>> duped into <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072</a> all concerned >>>>>> that the incorrect behavior currently implemented in all browsers >>>>>> prevents >>>>>> using it for the intended purposes. In particular, developers want to be >>>>>> able to use overscroll-behavior without the unpredictability of whether >>>>>> it >>>>>> applies depending on the layout of their scrolling content. >>>>>> >>>>>> Common uses for this include, >>>>>> 1. Preventing scrolling in inner widgets from chaining to document >>>>>> scrolls >>>>>> 2. Preventing scrolling on a dialog covering the page from chaining >>>>>> to and scrolling the page >>>>>> 3. Preventing scrolling on a menu from chaining to and scrolling the >>>>>> page. >>>>>> >>>>>> Right now, authors have to carefully ensure that they have overflow: >>>>>> auto and some scrolling content and then presumably hide the scrollbar in >>>>>> cases where they are only adding overflow: auto; to allow >>>>>> overscroll-behavior to apply. >>>>>> >>>>>> On Thu, Sep 11, 2025 at 4:06 PM Robert Flack <fla...@chromium.org> >>>>>> wrote: >>>>>> >>>>>>> Contact emailsfla...@chromium.org, perryuw...@gmail.com >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Specification >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-overscroll-1/#propdef-overscroll-behavior">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-overscroll-1/#propdef-overscroll-behavior</a> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Summary >>>>>>> >>>>>>> The overscroll-behavior applies to all scroll container elements, >>>>>>> regardless of whether those elements currently have overflowing content >>>>>>> or >>>>>>> are user scrollable. Developers can use overscroll-behavior to prevent >>>>>>> scroll propagation on an `overflow: hidden` backdrop or an `overflow: >>>>>>> auto` >>>>>>> element without needing to consider whether it will currently be >>>>>>> overflowing. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Blink componentBlink>Scroll >>>>>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EScroll%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EScroll%22</a>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Web Feature IDoverscroll-behavior >>>>>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/overscroll-behavior">https://webstatus.dev/features/overscroll-behavior</a>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> TAG reviewNone >>>>>>> >>>>>>> TAG review statusNot applicable >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Risks >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Interoperability and Compatibility >>>>>>> >>>>>>> This should be implemented on other browsers as well, as it matches >>>>>>> the specification. However, until this happens there are compatibility >>>>>>> risks that some sites may over accidentally set overscroll-behavior on >>>>>>> elements which don't currently apply today (either overflow: auto or not >>>>>>> having overflow) and will start applying, or that developers will rely >>>>>>> on >>>>>>> this behavior and have accidental scroll chaining in other browsers >>>>>>> until >>>>>>> they implement it as well. This change will affect a large number of >>>>>>> sites >>>>>>> per >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596</a>. >>>>>>> I have done compat analysis of many of the top sites affected by this in >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45</a> and found it >>>>>>> to either not have a meaningful impact or to better honor the developer >>>>>>> specified intent. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> *Gecko*: No signal >>>>>>> >>>>>>> *WebKit*: No signal >>>>>>> >>>>>>> *Web developers*: No signals >>>>>>> >>>>>>> *Other signals*: >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Ergonomics >>>>>>> >>>>>>> This improves the ergonomics of overscroll-behavior, fixing the >>>>>>> current unpredictable layout dependent behavior we have today. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Activation >>>>>>> >>>>>>> It may be difficult for developers to take advantage of this fix >>>>>>> before it is adopted in other browsers as it is likely not possible to >>>>>>> feature detect. They could remove pre-existing hacks to get this >>>>>>> functionality (i.e. ensuring 1px overflow) on supporting chromium >>>>>>> browsers. >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> WebView application risks >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such >>>>>>> that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based >>>>>>> applications? >>>>>>> >>>>>>> None >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Debuggability >>>>>>> >>>>>>> None >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, >>>>>>> Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?Yes >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests >>>>>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> >>>>>>> ?Yes >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-overscroll-behavior/overscroll-behavior-without-overflow.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-overscroll-behavior/overscroll-behavior-without-overflow.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Flag name on about://flagsNone >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Finch feature nameOverscrollBehaviorRespectedOnAllScrollContainers >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Rollout planWill ship enabled for all users >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Requires code in //chrome?False >>>>>>> >>>>>>> MeasurementThe OverscrollBehaviorOnNonScrollableScrollContainer >>>>>>> feature counter measures how often this new behavior is or would be >>>>>>> triggered. >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596</a> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Sample links >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://ebidel.github.io/demos/chatbox.html">https://ebidel.github.io/demos/chatbox.html</a> >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj">https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj</a> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Estimated milestones >>>>>>> >>>>>>> No milestones specified >>>>>>> >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Anticipated spec changes >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat >>>>>>> or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github >>>>>>> issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution >>>>>>> may >>>>>>> introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or >>>>>>> structure of >>>>>>> the API in a non-backward-compatible way). >>>>>>> None >>>>>>> >>>>>>> Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status >>>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5129635997941760?gate=5124735842910208">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5129635997941760?gate=5124735842910208</a> >>>>>>> >>>>>> -- >>>>>> You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google >>>>>> Groups "blink-dev" group. >>>>>> To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, >>>>>> send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. >>>>>> To view this discussion visit >>>>>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com</a> >>>>>> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>> >>>>>> . >>>>>> >>>>>

To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAARdPYdPV-itQEK%2BbSPAR0u3SfLOqvSEe57TA5SFKRDTODi16g%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAARdPYdPV-itQEK%2BbSPAR0u3SfLOqvSEe57TA5SFKRDTODi16g%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Respect overscroll-behavior on non-scrollable scroll containers
entry.summary: Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Respect overscroll-behavior on non-scrollable scroll containers
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22Re%5C%3A+%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Respect+overscroll%5C-behavior+on+non%5C-scrollable+scroll+containers%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">Re: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Respect overscroll-behavior on non-scrollable scroll containers</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Daniel+Bratell%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Daniel Bratell</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250917" rel="nofollow">Wed, 17 Sep 2025 08:36:32 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre style="margin: 0em;"> LGTM2 for the plan Philip outlined below.
/Daniel</pre><pre>
On 2025-09-17 17:28, Philip Jägenstedt wrote: </pre><blockquote style="border-left: #5555EE solid 0.2em; margin: 0em; padding-left: 0.85em"><tt>We discussed this at the API owners meeting today. (Present: Daniel, </tt><tt>Yoav, Alex, Chris, Mike, Dan, Vlad, me.) </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
LGTM1
</pre><tt>Based on the use counter (8%) and the number of sites checked (10) we </tt><tt>don't have high confidence that this won't break something. However, </tt><tt>we also don't have a concrete way to further reduce the uncertainty </tt><tt>beyond manually checking hundreds of sites and making a judgment call </tt><tt>about whether each is improved or not, which does not feel reasonable. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>Instead, to shake out as much breakage as we can, we'd like to let </tt><tt>this bake at 100% on beta for ~4 weeks (one extra milestone) and </tt><tt>monitor for bugs. If there's nothing concerning, then launch at 100% </tt><tt>on stable, while being prepared to revert if there are reports at that </tt><tt>point. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>If you could report back here before going to stable that would be </tt><tt>great, but no further approvals needed if things are looking good. </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"></pre><tt>On Wed, Sep 17, 2025 at 5:11 PM Alex Russell </tt><tt><slightly...@chromium.org> wrote: </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;">
Thanks. I'm pinging people. Hopefully folks can weigh in here quickly.
On Tuesday, September 16, 2025 at 7:11:54 AM UTC-7 Robert Flack wrote:
I completely agree, the point here isn't to follow the spec. The reason I think we should follow the spec in this case is that it is more ergonomic and predictable when applying overscroll-behavior doesn't just work sometimes. I think that developers are rightfully confused by those cases where it doesn't work which is why we have had several bugs filed about it.
I have reached out to a few web developers. If you know anyone who might have thoughts on this please loop them in as well.
On Mon, Sep 15, 2025 at 2:00 PM Alex Russell <slightly...@chromium.org> wrote:
I'd love for web developers who have been paying close attention to scroll behaviour to weigh in here. This has been a deep well of sadness in a cross-browser sense, and they might have opinions as to the benefits and costs we aren't able to easily see. Spec compliance can either be great or pointless, and it would be helpful to get a sense from folks building complex UIs which this is.
Best,
Alex
On Friday, September 12, 2025 at 10:53:50 AM UTC-7 Robert Flack wrote:
> is there any plausible pattern where web developers could depend on the current behavior intentionally?
The change in behavior comes in roughly three patterns:
1. overscroll-behavior: contain | none is specified on an element with overflow: hidden. In these cases the overscroll-behavior used to have no effect, scrolls would propagate past the element to ancestor scrollers. In practice, when a developer has specified this they likely intended to prevent scroll propagation, however due to the implementation it had no effect. Authors typically try to do this to prevent scrolling while a modal dialog is open from scrolling the content behind it, e.g. as in the example posted to the bug <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072</a>> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj">https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj</a>. 2. The author specified overscroll-behavior: contain | none but on an element with overflow-y: scroll | auto (but implicit overflow-x: hidden). In this case, they may have accidentally applied overscroll-behavior to both axes and not realized that by spec this prevents overscroll propagation in both axes. I observed this on <a rel="nofollow" href="https://lichess.org/">https://lichess.org/</a> though blocking horizontal scrolls on the open menu would not break using the site. 3. The author specified overscroll-behavior: contain | none on an element with overflow: scroll | auto. In this case, we have the unpredictable behavior that when you have overflow it prevents propagation, but if your containing element is large enough for its content then we don't. This is the common case for things like scrolling in a chat widget (demo <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://output.jsbin.com/helovikizu">https://output.jsbin.com/helovikizu</a>>, bug <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40748098">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40748098</a>>) or in an embedded frame (bug <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40736788">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40736788</a>>).
Case 1 and 2 are sort of the same, overflow: hidden now preventing scroll propagation, but in case 1 it never did anything before so it feels similar to an author using a property that doesn't work yet.
If we want to be conservative, we could only change the behavior for cases where it is currently layout dependent, i.e. case 3 overflow: auto | scroll. This would be an improvement however it wouldn't help with case 1 where you want to prevent scrolling from your component without risking that containing element becoming scrollable. Cases 1 and 2 are possible that developers are relying on this being incorrectly ignored and not preventing scroll propagation on overflow: hidden, similar to for example ignoring left or top on position: static.
That said, I do think it would be more useful and predictable for it to apply to all scroll containers as it is spec'd.
On Fri, Sep 12, 2025 at 4:15 AM Philip Jägenstedt <foo...@chromium.org> wrote:
Hey Rob,
Since the use counter is 8%, looking at 10 random popular sites doesn't reduce the upper bound of breakage by a whole lot. Using the rule of three <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rule_of_three_</a>(statistics)> gives 95% confidence that the rate of breakage is between 0 and 30%. But 30% of 8% is still a huge number when it comes to potential breakage. (Reducing this to a reasonable number with more random sampling isn't really feasible either, you'd need to test 800 sites with only negatives to get down to 0.03% if my math is right.)
The fact that the change seems to make things work better and aligns with apparent developer intention is great. But is there any plausible pattern where web developers could depend on the current behavior intentionally?
In a situation like this I think we should also consider how many sites we fix and not just how many we break. If we have high confidence that many sites will be improved but can't find any that would regress, then that seems like a good trade even if some regressions do surface.
If other vendors are interested in making the same change and there's clear developer demand, I think we should try it, with a Finch kill switch in place.
Best regards, Philip
On Thu, Sep 11, 2025 at 10:13 PM Robert Flack <fla...@chromium.org> wrote:
Note that this is a repost of
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/p2edIq4J-eQ/m/5MxPnuT8AwAJ">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/p2edIq4J-eQ/m/5MxPnuT8AwAJ</a> as an I2S instead of PSA as I am seeking and will await LGTMs considering the potential compat risk.
On the associated bug I have looked at a sampling of 10 popular sites affected by the overscroll-behavior change on httparchive <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45</a>> and found it to either not impact them or be beneficial: 1. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://lichess.org/">https://lichess.org/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://lichess.org/">https://lichess.org/</a>> On smaller screens the `#topnav` element opens in a menu. The application of overscroll behavior seems to be there to prevent scrolling the content and so this site will be improved by the change. 2. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://cardgames.io/">https://cardgames.io/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://cardgames.io/">https://cardgames.io/</a>> Seems to just be the body element that has overscrollBehavior set. This shouldn't be affected. 3. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://open.spotify.com/">https://open.spotify.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open.spotify.com/">https://open.spotify.com/</a>> The body and "your library" panel fit into this case. I think this change would apply the intended behavior as they do not seem to intend for the scroll to propagate. 4. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.accuweather.com/">https://www.accuweather.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.accuweather.com/">https://www.accuweather.com/</a>> Only the body has overscroll behavior specified. 5. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.ikea.com/">https://www.ikea.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.ikea.com/">https://www.ikea.com/</a>> Their mobile menu `#top-mobile-menu` has overscroll-behavior on it. This is presumably to prevent accidental pull to refresh while scrolling through the menu and would be fixed by this change. 6. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.tiktok.com/explore">https://www.tiktok.com/explore</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.tiktok.com/explore">https://www.tiktok.com/explore</a>> The side nav has contain overscroll-behavior. With this change you would no longer be able to scroll the main page by scrolling on top of the sidebar. This seems to be the intention but is not currently being honored. 7. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://x.com/">https://x.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://x.com/">https://x.com/</a>> Only the root element seems to have overscroll-behavior defined. 8. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://store.epicgames.com/">https://store.epicgames.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://store.epicgames.com/">https://store.epicgames.com/</a>> I'm unable to find the affected element 9. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.airbnb.com/">https://www.airbnb.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.airbnb.com/">https://www.airbnb.com/</a>> There are several scrolling containers with overscroll-behavior defined however I think these are only "not scrollable" while the page is loading. By the time the user interacts with them they have scrollable overflow and so are unaffected. The usage also seems to indicate they would not want scroll to chain past those containers. 10. <a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.expedia.com/">https://www.expedia.com/</a> <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.expedia.com/">https://www.expedia.com/</a>> I'm not able to find where the property is used.
In terms of developer demand, there are many bugs that have been duped into <a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072</a> all concerned that the incorrect behavior currently implemented in all browsers prevents using it for the intended purposes. In particular, developers want to be able to use overscroll-behavior without the unpredictability of whether it applies depending on the layout of their scrolling content.
Common uses for this include, 1. Preventing scrolling in inner widgets from chaining to document scrolls 2. Preventing scrolling on a dialog covering the page from chaining to and scrolling the page 3. Preventing scrolling on a menu from chaining to and scrolling the page.
Right now, authors have to carefully ensure that they have overflow: auto and some scrolling content and then presumably hide the scrollbar in cases where they are only adding overflow: auto; to allow overscroll-behavior to apply.
On Thu, Sep 11, 2025 at 4:06 PM Robert Flack <fla...@chromium.org> wrote:
Contact emails
fla...@chromium.org, perryuw...@gmail.com
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-overscroll-1/#propdef-overscroll-behavior">https://www.w3.org/TR/css-overscroll-1/#propdef-overscroll-behavior</a>
Summary
The overscroll-behavior applies to all scroll container elements, regardless of whether those elements currently have overflowing content or are user scrollable. Developers can use overscroll-behavior to prevent scroll propagation on an `overflow: hidden` backdrop or an `overflow: auto` element without needing to consider whether it will currently be overflowing.
Blink component
Blink>Scroll
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EScroll%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EScroll%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
overscroll-behavior <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://webstatus.dev/features/overscroll-behavior">https://webstatus.dev/features/overscroll-behavior</a>>
TAG review
None
TAG review status
Not applicable
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
This should be implemented on other browsers as well, as it matches the specification. However, until this happens there are compatibility risks that some sites may over accidentally set overscroll-behavior on elements which don't currently apply today (either overflow: auto or not having overflow) and will start applying, or that developers will rely on this behavior and have accidental scroll chaining in other browsers until they implement it as well. This change will affect a large number of sites per
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596</a>. I have done compat analysis of many of the top sites affected by this in
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45 and">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41371072#comment45 and</a> found it to either not have a meaningful impact or to better honor the developer specified intent.
/Gecko/: No signal
/WebKit/: No signal
/Web developers/: No signals
/Other signals/:
Ergonomics
This improves the ergonomics of overscroll-behavior, fixing the current unpredictable layout dependent behavior we have today.
Activation
It may be difficult for developers to take advantage of this fix before it is adopted in other browsers as it is likely not possible to feature detect. They could remove pre-existing hacks to get this functionality (i.e. ensuring 1px overflow) on supporting chromium browsers.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
None
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>>?
Yes
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-overscroll-behavior/overscroll-behavior-without-overflow.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-overscroll-behavior/overscroll-behavior-without-overflow.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-overscroll-behavior/overscroll-behavior-without-overflow.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned">https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-overscroll-behavior/overscroll-behavior-without-overflow.html?label=experimental&label=master&aligned</a>>
Flag name on about://flags
None
Finch feature name
OverscrollBehaviorRespectedOnAllScrollContainers
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Measurement
The OverscrollBehaviorOnNonScrollableScrollContainer feature counter measures how often this new behavior is or would be triggered.
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596">https://chromestatus.com/metrics/feature/timeline/popularity/5596</a>
Sample links
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://ebidel.github.io/demos/chatbox.html">https://ebidel.github.io/demos/chatbox.html</a> <a rel="nofollow" href="https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj">https://codepen.io/rctneil/pen/rJYONj</a>
Estimated milestones
No milestones specified
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
None
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5129635997941760?gate=5124735842910208">https://chromestatus.com/feature/5129635997941760?gate=5124735842910208</a>
</pre><tt> -- </tt><tt> You received this message because you are </tt><pre style="margin: 0em;"> subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com</a>
<<a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAJh39TPripgF_DY4adqs9wbtQV8XRTVdXER3SOR0-52SczULBA%40mail.gmail.com?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer</a>>.

entry.title: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interest Invokers (the `interestfor` attribute)
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interest Invokers (the `interestfor` attribute)
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Interest+Invokers+%5C%28the+%60interestfor%60+attribute%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Intent to Ship: Interest Invokers (the `interestfor` attribute)</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Mason+Freed%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Mason Freed</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250918" rel="nofollow">Thu, 18 Sep 2025 13:38:19 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>Contact emails
mas...@chromium.org, chrom...@keithcirkel.co.uk</pre><pre>
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer">https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos">https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos</a>
Summary
This feature adds an `interestfor` attribute to <button> and <a> elements. This attribute adds "interest" behaviors to the element, such that when the user "shows interest" in the element, actions are triggered on the target element, such as showing a popover. The user agent will handle detecting when the user "shows interest" in the element, via methods such as hovering the element with a mouse, hitting special hotkeys on the keyboard, or long-pressing the element on touchscreens. When interest is shown or lost, an `InterestEvent` will be fired on the target, which have default actions in the case of popovers - showing and hiding the popover.
Blink component
Blink>DOM <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EDOM%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EDOM%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features/pull/3275">https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features/pull/3275</a>
Search tags
interestfor <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:interestfor">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:interestfor</a>>, invokers <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:invokers">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:invokers</a>>
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058</a>
TAG review status
Issues addressed
Origin Trial Name
The interesttarget Attribute
Chromium Trial Name
HTMLInterestTargetAttribute
Origin Trial documentation link
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer">https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer</a>
WebFeature UseCounter name
kInterestTarget
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Note: There are interop issues due to WebKit. WebKit has expressed opposition <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3266951344">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3266951344</a>> to supporting the "tooltip" use case, citing the lack of "a consistent and reliable way to get to tooltip-like information [on touchscreen]". This is despite *long-press* being the de-facto standard for exactly that interaction pattern, for at least a decade if not longer. See, for example, UIKit's long-press documentation <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/handling-long-press-gestures">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/handling-long-press-gestures</a>>, the following comment <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3267037840">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3267037840</a>> on the standards issue, and a similar comment <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2493546945">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2493546945</a>> from a year ago which also did not receive a response by WebKit. In addition, WebKit's opinion states that they are unable to identify an interface mechanism for `interestfor` on spatial computing devices. I've suggested <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2287429935">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2287429935</a>> that one option is to mandate a particular behavior for these devices, but that comment was ignored.
Importantly, the TAG review was marked Supportive <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058</a>> for this overall API proposal.
Gecko: Defer <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181</a>> The comments are generally supportive, but without going so far as to mark the issue with "Support". The general tone is supportive of "option 3", which is the one being pursued, to add an item to the context menu on mobile interfaces.
WebKit: Negative <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/464">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/464</a>> This position is not explicitly marked as negative, but the comments (including in the linked HTML issue) are negative: "We therefore remain opposed to this feature"
Web developers: Strongly positive <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181#issuecomment-3097924236">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181#issuecomment-3097924236</a>> See the linked comment, for a summary of developer opinions from multiple venues. Developers are highly positive on this feature, recognizing the fact that 94+% <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11Bt_FCAqu1hd5llGRGpzgwlgHaqLmOC4SJEMRtNQY-g/edit?gid=0">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11Bt_FCAqu1hd5llGRGpzgwlgHaqLmOC4SJEMRtNQY-g/edit?gid=0</a>> of top-50 production sites use some form of hover-triggered UI.
Other signals:
Ergonomics
The `popover=hint` API is a fairly important companion API to this one, providing a way to *not* close other unrelated `popover=auto` popover stacks when a tooltip UX is shown.
Activation
There is a polyfill <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor">https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor</a>> which can be used to mitigate a lack of browser support. See the explainer's touchscreen section <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer/#touchscreen">https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer/#touchscreen</a>> for more detail, but since users need to maintain access to the UA-provided <a> long-press context menu, it isn’t possible for the polyfill to support touchscreen long-press on <a> elements without canceling the context menu. Importantly, however, due to this same limitation, almost no production sites today support touchscreen activation of hovercards on links. So the activation story should be fairly good: no loss of functionality on browsers relying on the polyfill, and an enhanced story on touchscreen for browsers natively supporting the feature.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
There should not be any WebView risk. It's possible that if WebView apps suppress the context menu, then content that uses `interestfor` will not be available within those apps. However, presumably in such an app, the long press gesture is already being intercepted to provide a tooltip or app-provided menu, and that will continue to function.
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
Yes: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/html/semantics/interestfor">https://wpt.fyi/results/html/semantics/interestfor</a>
Flag name on about://flags
Experimental Web Platform Features
Finch feature name
HTMLInterestForAttribute
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/326681249">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/326681249</a>
Availability expectation
Unknown, due to WebKit objections.
Adoption expectation
With the polyfill <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor">https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor</a>>, it is my hope that adoption can proceed for some sites before Baseline status. That remains to be seen.
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop 142 Origin trial desktop first 135 Origin trial desktop last 137 Origin trial extension 1 end milestone 140 DevTrial on desktop 133 Shipping on Android 142 Origin trial Android first 135 Origin trial Android last 137 DevTrial on Android 133 Shipping on WebView 142 Origin trial WebView first 135 Origin trial WebView last 137
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
Since WebKit is objecting to the feature, the HTML spec PR <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006</a>> cannot land. It's possible that in the future, when WebKit reviewers give it a review, they find things that they would like to change. Given all of the opportunities provided to them to give this feedback early, we should be highly reluctant to make such changes. However, they are at least possible. The CSS specs have landed in drafts (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest</a> and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos">https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos</a>). Those were the result of active discussions in the CSSWG on multiple occasions, with significant feedback from the participants. So I would consider those to be lower risk of changing.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/4530756656562176?gate=6100172066258944">https://chromestatus.com/feature/4530756656562176?gate=6100172066258944</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions

entry.title: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Interest Invokers (the `interestfor` attribute)
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Interest Invokers (the `interestfor` attribute)
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Re%5C%3A+Intent+to+Ship%5C%3A+Interest+Invokers+%5C%28the+%60interestfor%60+attribute%5C%29%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Re: Intent to Ship: Interest Invokers (the `interestfor` attribute)</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22Yoav+Weiss+%5C%28%40Shopify%5C%29%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">Yoav Weiss (@Shopify)</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250919" rel="nofollow">Fri, 19 Sep 2025 01:23:18 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>LGTM2
On Friday, September 19, 2025 at 3:16:37 AM UTC+2 Domenic Denicola wrote:</pre><pre>
LGTM1.
While it's unfortunate that the path to interop here might take longer than we've hoped, it's very clear from the abundant linked documentation that the team has done everything possible to set this feature up for success, and meet the high bar set by our process. The spec PR has received detailed review; the WPTs are comprehensive; a polyfill is ready; and perhaps most importantly, the API has gathered ~3.5 years worth of broad feedback which has shaped and improved it substantially. In my opinion, there's nothing more we could ask for, from an API owners perspective. On Friday, September 19, 2025 at 5:38:28 AM UTC+9 Mason Freed wrote:
Contact emails
mas...@chromium.org, chrom...@keithcirkel.co.uk
Explainer
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer">https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer</a>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest</a>
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos">https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos</a>
Summary
This feature adds an `interestfor` attribute to <button> and <a> elements. This attribute adds "interest" behaviors to the element, such that when the user "shows interest" in the element, actions are triggered on the target element, such as showing a popover. The user agent will handle detecting when the user "shows interest" in the element, via methods such as hovering the element with a mouse, hitting special hotkeys on the keyboard, or long-pressing the element on touchscreens. When interest is shown or lost, an `InterestEvent` will be fired on the target, which have default actions in the case of popovers - showing and hiding the popover.
Blink component
Blink>DOM <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EDOM%22">https://issues.chromium.org/issues?q=customfield1222907:%22Blink%3EDOM%22</a>>
Web Feature ID
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features/pull/3275">https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features/pull/3275</a>
Search tags
interestfor <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:interestfor">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:interestfor</a>>, invokers <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:invokers">https://chromestatus.com/features#tags:invokers</a>>
TAG review
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058</a>
TAG review status
Issues addressed
Origin Trial Name
The interesttarget Attribute
Chromium Trial Name
HTMLInterestTargetAttribute
Origin Trial documentation link
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer">https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer</a>
WebFeature UseCounter name
kInterestTarget
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Note: There are interop issues due to WebKit. WebKit has expressed opposition <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3266951344">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3266951344</a>> to supporting the "tooltip" use case, citing the lack of "a consistent and reliable way to get to tooltip-like information [on touchscreen]". This is despite *long-press* being the de-facto standard for exactly that interaction pattern, for at least a decade if not longer. See, for example, UIKit's long-press documentation <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/handling-long-press-gestures">https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/handling-long-press-gestures</a>>, the following comment <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3267037840">https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10309#issuecomment-3267037840</a>> on the standards issue, and a similar comment <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2493546945">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2493546945</a>>
from a year ago which also did not receive a response by WebKit. In addition, WebKit's opinion states that they are unable to identify an interface mechanism for `interestfor` on spatial computing devices. I've suggested <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2287429935">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/305#issuecomment-2287429935</a>>
that one option is to mandate a particular behavior for these devices, but that comment was ignored.
Am I wrong to think that if a future mobile interaction would be a better fit for showing "interest" than long-press, UAs can simply wire it to use this APIs semantics?
Importantly, the TAG review was marked Supportive <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058">https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/1058</a>> for this overall API proposal.
Gecko: Defer <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181</a>> The comments are generally supportive, but without going so far as to mark the issue with "Support". The general tone is supportive of "option 3", which is the one being pursued, to add an item to the context menu on mobile interfaces.
Again, the implemented option feels like a UX decision by the browser and can change over time, right? (I personally prefer option 2 or even option 4 + extra tap to open the menu, but what do I know..)
WebKit: Negative <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/464">https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/464</a>> This position is not explicitly marked as negative, but the comments (including in the linked HTML issue) are negative: "We therefore remain opposed to this feature"
Web developers: Strongly positive <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181#issuecomment-3097924236">https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/1181#issuecomment-3097924236</a>>
See the linked comment, for a summary of developer opinions from multiple venues. Developers are highly positive on this feature, recognizing the fact that 94+% <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11Bt_FCAqu1hd5llGRGpzgwlgHaqLmOC4SJEMRtNQY-g/edit?gid=0">https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/11Bt_FCAqu1hd5llGRGpzgwlgHaqLmOC4SJEMRtNQY-g/edit?gid=0</a>>
of top-50 production sites use some form of hover-triggered UI.
With my Shopify hat on, I can attest to the developer need for this.
Other signals:
Ergonomics
The `popover=hint` API is a fairly important companion API to this one, providing a way to *not* close other unrelated `popover=auto` popover stacks when a tooltip UX is shown.
Activation
There is a polyfill <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor">https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor</a>> which can be used to mitigate a lack of browser support. See the explainer's touchscreen section <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer/#touchscreen">https://open-ui.org/components/interest-invokers.explainer/#touchscreen</a>> for more detail, but since users need to maintain access to the UA-provided <a> long-press context menu, it isn’t possible for the polyfill to support touchscreen long-press on <a> elements without canceling the context menu. Importantly, however, due to this same limitation, almost no production sites today support touchscreen activation of hovercards on links. So the activation story should be fairly good: no loss of functionality on browsers relying on the polyfill, and an enhanced story on touchscreen for browsers natively supporting the feature.
WebView application risks
Does this intent deprecate or change behavior of existing APIs, such that it has potentially high risk for Android WebView-based applications?
There should not be any WebView risk. It's possible that if WebView apps suppress the context menu, then content that uses `interestfor` will not be available within those apps. However, presumably in such an app, the long press gesture is already being intercepted to provide a tooltip or app-provided menu, and that will continue to function.
Debuggability
None
Will this feature be supported on all six Blink platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, ChromeOS, Android, and Android WebView)?
Yes
Is this feature fully tested by web-platform-tests <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md">https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/docs/testing/web_platform_tests.md</a>> ?
Yes: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/html/semantics/interestfor">https://wpt.fyi/results/html/semantics/interestfor</a>
Flag name on about://flags
Experimental Web Platform Features
Finch feature name
HTMLInterestForAttribute
Rollout plan
Will ship enabled for all users
Requires code in //chrome?
False
Tracking bug
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://issues.chromium.org/issues/326681249">https://issues.chromium.org/issues/326681249</a>
Availability expectation
Unknown, due to WebKit objections.
Adoption expectation
With the polyfill <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor">https://github.com/mfreed7/interestfor</a>>, it is my hope that adoption can proceed for some sites before Baseline status. That remains to be seen.
Estimated milestones Shipping on desktop142Origin trial desktop first135Origin trial desktop last 137Origin trial extension 1 end milestone140DevTrial on desktop133Shipping on Android142Origin trial Android first135Origin trial Android last137DevTrial on Android133Shipping on WebView142Origin trial WebView first135Origin trial WebView last137
Anticipated spec changes
Open questions about a feature may be a source of future web compat or interop issues. Please list open issues (e.g. links to known github issues in the project for the feature specification) whose resolution may introduce web compat/interop risk (e.g., changing to naming or structure of the API in a non-backward-compatible way).
Since WebKit is objecting to the feature, the HTML spec PR <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006">https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/11006</a>> cannot land. It's possible that in the future, when WebKit reviewers give it a review, they find things that they would like to change. Given all of the opportunities provided to them to give this feedback early, we should be highly reluctant to make such changes. However, they are at least possible. The CSS specs have landed in drafts (<a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest">https://drafts.csswg.org/css-ui-4/#interest</a> and <a rel="nofollow" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos">https://drafts.csswg.org/selectors/#interest-pseudos</a>). Those were the result of active discussions in the CSSWG on multiple occasions, with significant feedback from the participants. So I would consider those to be lower risk of changing.
Link to entry on the Chrome Platform Status
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/4530756656562176?gate=6100172066258944">https://chromestatus.com/feature/4530756656562176?gate=6100172066258944</a>
Links to previous Intent discussions
Intent to Prototype: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/ch">https://groups.google.com/a/ch</a> romium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/B7F891EB-32FE-48FD-B54B-E452AD 74CC3E%40igalia.com
Intent to Experiment: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/ch">https://groups.google.com/a/ch</a> romium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM%3DNeDiTCMXnR6D-5XdYiwgV_ FMAKE8VM%2Bq-Pyho9KZqoDpSjQ%40mail.gmail.com
Intent to Extend Experiment 1: <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/ch">https://groups.google.com/a/ch</a> romium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAM%3DNeDhZosgitNVTVqQ%3DzznM0 JxiH8d0ZoGBManBaE6ByUJ0%2Bg%40mail.gmail.com
This intent message was generated by Chrome Platform Status <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://chromestatus.com/">https://chromestatus.com/</a>>.
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/097ddcf4-90b6-4d7d-b608-dba5f95593aan%40chromium.org">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/097ddcf4-90b6-4d7d-b608-dba5f95593aan%40chromium.org</a>. </pre>
</div>

entry.title: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: Cross-Tab Region Capture
entry.summary: [blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: Cross-Tab Region Capture
entry.content:
<div class="msgHead"> <h1> <span class="subject"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=subject:%22%5C%5Bblink%5C-dev%5C%5D+Web%5C-Facing+Change+PSA%5C%3A+Cross%5C-Tab+Region+Capture%22&o=newest" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="name">[blink-dev] Web-Facing Change PSA: Cross-Tab Region Capture</span></a></span> </h1> <p class="darkgray font13"> <span class="sender pipe"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=from:%22%27Elad+Alon%27+via+blink%5C-dev%22" rel="nofollow"><span itemprop="author" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"><span itemprop="name">'Elad Alon' via blink-dev</span></span></a></span> <span class="date"><a href="/search?l=blink-dev@chromium.org&q=date:20250919" rel="nofollow">Fri, 19 Sep 2025 04:50:07 -0700</a></span> </p> </div><div itemprop="articleBody" class="msgBody">
<pre>*Contact emails*
elada...@chromium.org</pre><pre>
Specification
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-region/">https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-region/</a>
Summary
Using the (pre-existing) Screen Capture API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/screen-capture/">https://www.w3.org/TR/screen-capture/</a>>, Web applications can prompt the user to screen-share a tab, a window or a screen, resulting in a MediaStream that contains a video MediaStreamTrack that can be consumed locally or transmitted remotely. Further, Web applications can use the (pre-existing) Region Capture API <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-region/">https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-region/</a>> to crop this video track, removing all pixels that fall outside the bounding box of a target element; this is done using the MediaStreamTrack.cropTo() <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/BrowserCaptureMediaStreamTrack/cropTo">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/BrowserCaptureMediaStreamTrack/cropTo</a>> method, which accepts as input a CropTarget <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CropTarget">https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CropTarget</a>> object that is associated with said “target element”.
Previously, successful calls to cropTo() would require:
1.
The target element is within the captured tab. 2.
The captured tab is the capturing tab. (That is, the app is capturing its own tab.)
Following a spec change <<a rel="nofollow" href="https://github.com/w3c/mediacapture-region/pull/74/files">https://github.com/w3c/mediacapture-region/pull/74/files</a>> made three years ago, and following a consultation with Chrome Security, the second of these two conditions is now being removed, starting m142. (There is, of course, no intention of ever removing the first.)
Risks
Interoperability and Compatibility
Gecko: No signal (Their representative Jan-Ivar Bruaroey approved merging the aforementioned PR into the spec back in 2022.)
WebKit: No signal (Their representative Youenn Fablet approved merging the aforementioned PR into the spec back in 2022.)
Flag name on about://flags
chrome://flags/#region-capture-cross-tab
Finch feature name
RegionCaptureOfOtherTabs
Sample links
<a rel="nofollow" href="https://eladalon1983.github.io/cross-tab-region-capture/">https://eladalon1983.github.io/cross-tab-region-capture/</a>
Estimated milestones
Shipping on desktop
142
-- You received this message because you are subscribed to the Google Groups "blink-dev" group. To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to blink-dev+unsubscr...@chromium.org. To view this discussion visit <a rel="nofollow" href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAMO6jDNVv4%2Bp1hWnXZ7VjAKox-Jtt92AUj3cOxdtkHzEgP2OHg%40mail.gmail.com">https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msgid/blink-dev/CAMO6jDNVv4%2Bp1hWnXZ7VjAKox-Jtt92AUj3cOxdtkHzEgP2OHg%40mail.gmail.com</a>. </pre>
</div>
